ygData.subject: RE: [rest-discuss] the "profile" link relation type
ygData.msgSnippet: By mistake I meant creating invalid expectations. I m quite sure most Web developers out there don t know that namespaces in XML, e.g., are not and were

By "mistake" I meant creating invalid expectations. I'm quite sure most Web
developers out there don't know that namespaces in XML, e.g., are not and
were never expected to be dereferenced. I can't find the link now but quite
some time ago I tried to look one of those up and landed at a W3 page that
explained that they are getting tens of gigabytes of traffic a day because
tools try to continuously dereference those URIs.


--
Markus Lanthaler
@markuslanthaler




> -----Original Message-----
> From: Moore, Jonathan (CIM) [mailto:Jonathan_Moore@...]
> Sent: Tuesday, March 06, 2012 10:07 PM
> To: Markus Lanthaler
> Cc: Erik Wilde; REST Discuss
> Subject: Re: [rest-discuss] the "profile" link relation type
> 
> Can you clarify the "mistake" you're referencing?  I'm not following
> how the distinction affects interoperability--can't a client treat a
> URL that happens to 404 (perhaps due to a temporary outage) the same
> way it would treat a URN here?
> 
> Jon
> ........
> Jon Moore
> 
> 
> On Mar 6, 2012, at 8:01 AM, "Markus Lanthaler"
> <markus.lanthaler@...> wrote:
> 
> > Moore, Jonathan wrote on Tuesday, March 06, 2012 8:12 PM:
> >> Specifying a URI allows you to use both non-dereferenceable
> >> URNs as well as dereferenceable URLs. Documenting the syntax
> >> as a URI makes it clear that the semantics treat this as an
> >> (opaque) identifier when processing.
> >
> > I agree. That's why I talked about *HTTP* URIs and using a different
> scheme
> > for non-dereferenceable ones. The I-D should be clear about that.
> That's all
> > I wanted to say..
> >
> >
> > --
> > Markus Lanthaler
> > @markuslanthaler
> >
> >
> >
> >
